subject: WIP: Ensure a cluster is only ever managed by a single Nova compute
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-11 15:21:25.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/vmwareapi/driver.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/009ce2cef72e7ae6d2e13f6283e5893e95f58cc8', 'message': "WIP: Ensure a cluster is only ever managed by a single Nova compute

This is a proposed fix for:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1419785

The above happens when you configure 2 HA nodes with different
hostnames to manage the same cluster. On failover, badness ensues when
the incorrectly hostnamed standby tries to take over.

It would be nice to fix the badness, however it is currently very
deeply engrained in Nova. Lots of things assume a consistent 'host',
and they will all be broken in this scenario. Instead, this patch
detects a change of Nova compute, and rejects it.

During the driver's init_host it checks all managed clusters for the
custom value 'openstack_compute_host'. If the value is not present, it
sets it to the current host. If it is, it checks it against the
current hostname. It will raise an Exception if any non-matching
values are found, which in turn will cause Nova to fail to start.

Change-Id: I70ddb491e57b71ddba78cb0cdc39d8d885882d88
Closes-bug: #1419785
"}]
commit_message:
WIP: Ensure a cluster is only ever managed by a single Nova compute

This is a proposed fix for:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1419785

The above happens when you configure 2 HA nodes with different
hostnames to manage the same cluster. On failover, badness ensues when
the incorrectly hostnamed standby tries to take over.

It would be nice to fix the badness, however it is currently very
deeply engrained in Nova. Lots of things assume a consistent 'host',
and they will all be broken in this scenario. Instead, this patch
detects a change of Nova compute, and rejects it.

During the driver's init_host it checks all managed clusters for the
custom value 'openstack_compute_host'. If the value is not present, it
sets it to the current host. If it is, it checks it against the
current hostname. It will raise an Exception if any non-matching
values are found, which in turn will cause Nova to fail to start.

Change-Id: I70ddb491e57b71ddba78cb0cdc39d8d885882d88
Closes-bug: #1419785
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/07/154907/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Find or create custom field definition 'openstack_compute_host', # which can be attached to ClusterComputeResource. # N.B. This requires vSphere privilege Global.ManageCustomFields cfm = vim.service_content.customFieldsManager fields = self._session._call_method(vim_util, 'get_object_property', cfm, 'field') if fields is not None: fields = getattr(fields, 'CustomFieldDef', []) else: fields = [] for field in fields: if field.name == 'openstack_compute_host': field_key = field.key break else: field_def = vim.AddCustomFieldDef( cfm, name='openstack_compute_host', moType='vim.ClusterComputeResource') field_key = field_def.key # Iterate through all managed clusters. If they don't have # 'openstack_compute_host', set it to this host. If they do, ensure its # value is the same as this host. Die if it isn't. cluster_mors = set([x['cluster_mor'] for x in self.dict_mors.values()]) for cluster in cluster_mors: values = self._session._call_method(vim_util, 'get_object_property', cluster, 'value') if values is not None: values = getattr(values, 'CustomFieldValue', []) else: values = [] for value in values: if value.key == field_key: if value.value != host: raise Exception("Badness will ensue") break else: vim.SetField(cfm, entity=cluster, key=field_key, value=host)

commit_message:
update epel version number in epel element

epel-release 7.2 has been superseded by 7.5, so update accordingly.
this time, detect the available epel-release package from the repo
instead of hardcoding version number which will break build each
time the version number gets bumped up.

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst . Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None For help with syntax, see http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html To test out your formatting, see http://www.tele3.cz/jbar/rest/rest.html ============================= Native Keystone Resources ============================= Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/keystone-resources Problem description =================== Some cloud operators would like to be able to use Heat templates to manage users, tenants and roles in Keystone. Currently we can only create users, and only through an AWS IAM resource type. This was discussed on the mailing list in the thread beginning here: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-January/055554.html Proposed change =============== Implement the following native resource types: - OS::Keystone::User - name - tenant-id (optional) - email (optional) - initial-pass (optional) - enabled (default True) - roles (list) - tenant - role - OS::Keystone::Role - name - OS::Keystone::Tenant - name - description (optional) - enabled (default True) Since in the default policy.json configuration these APIs are available only to administrative users, the plugin would be in the /contrib tree and not installed by default. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- This a blueprint where I'm throwing it out there to see who picks it up. Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Kilo-3 Work Items ---------- - User plugin - Role plugin - Tenant plugin Dependencies ============ None

commit_message:
Change in default location of log file

The default log file was '/var/log/freezer.log' which
is usually non user writable. That resulted in an exception being
raised when run as a normal user without specifying a writable
location

Now freezer still tries to write to '/var/log/freezer.log',
but falls back to '~/.freezer/freezer.log' in case of error

Errors while opening log file won't print the traceback anymore,
but result in simple error message and coherent exit value.

Change-Id: I17d0421b049f18417f21df81cb48b6fad76829e6
Closes-Bug: #1420842

added_lines: def configure_log_file_using_defaults(): def configure_logging(file_name): expanded_file_name = os.path.expanduser(file_name) logging.basicConfig( filename=expanded_file_name, level=logging.INFO, format='%(asctime)s %(name)s %(levelname)s %(message)s') return expanded_file_name if backup_args.log_file: return configure_logging(backup_args.log_file) for file_name in ['/var/log/freezer.log', '~/freezer.log']: try: return configure_logging(file_name) except Exception as e: pass raise Exception("Unable to write to log file") def fail(exit_code, e, do_log=True): if do_log: logging.critical(msg) try: log_file_name = configure_log_file_using_defaults() except Exception as err: fail(1, err, do_log=False) if not backup_args.quiet: print 'log file at {0}'.format(log_file_name)
